unnormalised: New Delhi Grapples with Deteriorating Air Quality Post-Diwali
normalised: New Delhi Grapples with Deteriorating Air Quality Post-Diwali

unnormalised: New Delhi, November 7th – Air quality in the National Capital Region has plummeted following the Diwali celebrations, reaching hazardous levels according to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). The Air Quality Index (AQI) soared to an average of 450 in several areas, categorized as ‘severe’, posing significant health risks, especially to children and the elderly.
normalised: New Delhi, seventh November – Air quality in the National Capital Region has plummeted following the Diwali celebrations, reaching hazardous levels according to the C P C B. The Air Quality Index (A Q I) soared to an average of four hundred and fifty in several areas, categorized as ‘severe’, posing significant health risks, especially to children and the elderly.

unnormalised: Experts attribute the sharp decline to a combination of factors, including bursting of firecrackers despite bans, stubble burning in neighboring states like Punjab and Haryana, and unfavorable meteorological conditions hindering dispersal of pollutants. The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has urged state governments to implement stricter measures to curb pollution sources.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma from AIIMS Delhi warned about the increased incidence of respiratory illnesses and advised citizens to limit outdoor activities. The spike coincides with the post-Diwali festivities when many families indulge in traditional sweets and dishes, often prepared using fuels that contribute to indoor air pollution. Despite awareness campaigns, the prevalence of pollutants remains a pressing concern requiring sustained efforts. Levels are expected to remain elevated until wind speeds pick up, potentially impacting celebrations around upcoming festivals like Onam.
